1.title: Percievable
1.description: Information and user interface components must be presentable to users in ways they can perceive.

1.title: Text Alternatives
1.description: Provide text alternatives for any non-text content so that it can be changed into other forms people need, such as large print, braille, speech, symbols or simpler language.

1.title: Non-text Content
1.description: All non-text content that is presented to the user has a text alternative that serves the equivalent purpose, except for the situations listed below.

1.title: Audio-only and Video-only (Prerecorded)
1.description: For prerecorded audio-only and prerecorded video-only media, the following are true, except when the audio or video is a media alternative for text and is clearly labeled as such:

2.title: Captions (Prerecorded)
2.description: Captions are provided for all prerecorded audio content in synchronized media, except when the media is a media alternative for text and is clearly labeled as such.

3.title: Audio Description or Media Alternative (Prerecorded)
3.description: An alternative for time-based media or audio description of the prerecorded video content is provided for synchronized media, except when the media is a media alternative for text and is clearly labeled as such.

4.title: Captions (Live)
4.description: Captions are provided for all live audio content in synchronized media.

5.title: Audio Description (Prerecorded)
5.description: Audio description is provided for all prerecorded video content in synchronized media.

3.title: Adaptable
3.description: Create content that can be presented in different ways (for example simpler layout) without losing information or structure.

1.title: Info and Relationships
1.description: Information, structure, and relationships conveyed through presentation can be programmatically determined or are available in text.

2.title: Meaningful Sequence
2.description: When the sequence in which content is presented affects its meaning, a correct reading sequence can be programmatically determined.

3.title: Sensory Characteristics
3.description: Instructions provided for understanding and operating content do not rely solely on sensory characteristics of components such as shape, color, size, visual location, orientation, or sound.

4.title: Orientation
4.description: Content does not restrict its view and operation to a single display orientation, such as portrait or landscape, unless a specific display orientation is essential.

5.title: Identify Input Purpose
5.description: The purpose of each input field collecting information about the user can be programmatically determined when:

4.title: Distinguishible
4.description: Make it easier for users to see and hear content including separating foreground from background.

1.title: Use of Color
1.description: Color is not used as the only visual means of conveying information, indicating an action, prompting a response, or distinguishing a visual element.

2.title: Audio Control
2.description: If any audio on a Web page plays automatically for more than 3 seconds, either a mechanism is available to pause or stop the audio, or a mechanism is available to control audio volume independently from the overall system volume level.

3.title: Contrast (Minimum)
3.description: The visual presentation of text and images of text has a contrast ratio of at least 4.5:1, except for the following:

4.title: Resize Text
4.description: Except for captions and images of text, text can be resized without assistive technology up to 200 percent without loss of content or functionality.

5.title: Images of Text
5.description: If the technologies being used can achieve the visual presentation, text is used to convey information rather than images of text except for the following:

2.title: Operable
2.description: User interface components and navigation must be operable.

1.title: Keyboard Accessible
1.description: Make all functionality available from a keyboard

1.title: Keyboard
1.description: All functionality of the content is operable through a keyboard interface without requiring specific timings for individual keystrokes, except where the underlying function requires input that depends on the path of the user's movement and not just the endpoints.

2.title: No Keyboard Trap
2.description: If keyboard focus can be moved to a component of the page using a keyboard interface, then focus can be moved away from that component using only a keyboard interface, and, if it requires more than unmodified arrow or tab keys or other standard exit methods, the user is advised of the method for moving focus away.

4.title: Character Key Shortcuts
4.description: If a keyboard shortcut is implemented in content using only letter (including upper- and lower-case letters), punctuation, number, or symbol characters, then at least one of the following is true:

2.title: Enough Time
2.description: Provide users enough time to read and use content.

1.title: Timing Adjustable
1.description: For each time limit that is set by the content, at least one of the following is true:

2.title: Pause, Stop, Hide
2.description: For moving, blinking, scrolling, or auto-updating information, all of the following are true:

3.title: Seizures and Physical Reactions
3.description: Do not design content in a way that is known to cause seizures or physical reactions.

1.title: Three Flashes or Below Threshold
1.description: Web pages do not contain anything that flashes more than three times in any one second period, or the flash is below the general flash and red flash thresholds.

4.title: Navigable
4.description: Provide ways to help users navigate, find content, and determine where they are.

1.title: Bypass Blocks
1.description: A mechanism is available to bypass blocks of content that are repeated on multiple Web pages.

2.title: Page Titled
2.description: Web pages have titles that describe topic or purpose.

3.title: Focus Order
3.description: If a Web page can be navigated sequentially and the navigation sequences affect meaning or operation, focusable components receive focus in an order that preserves meaning and operability.

4.title: Link Purpose (In Context)
4.description: The purpose of each link can be determined from the link text alone or from the link text together with its programmatically determined link context, except where the purpose of the link would be ambiguous to users in general.

5.title: Multiple Ways
5.description: More than one way is available to locate a Web page within a set of Web pages except where the Web Page is the result of, or a step in, a process.

6.title: Headings and Labels
6.description: Headings and labels describe topic or purpose.

7.title: Focus Visible
7.description: Any keyboard operable user interface has a mode of operation where the keyboard focus indicator is visible.

5.title: Input Modalities
5.description: Make it easier for users to operate functionality through various inputs beyond keyboard.

1.title: Pointer Gestures
1.description: All functionality that uses multipoint or path-based gestures for operation can be operated with a single pointer without a path-based gesture, unless a multipoint or path-based gesture is essential.

2.title: Pointer Cancellation
2.description: For functionality that can be operated using a single pointer, at least one of the following is true:

3.title: Label in Name
3.description: For user interface components with labels that include text or images of text, the name contains the text that is presented visually.

4.title: Motion Actuation
4.description: Functionality that can be operated by device motion or user motion can also be operated by user interface components and responding to the motion can be disabled to prevent accidental actuation, except when:

3.title: Understandable
3.description: Information and the operation of the user interface must be understandable.

1.title: Readable
1.description: Make text content readable and understandable.

2.title: Predictable
2.description: Make Web pages appear and operate in predictable ways.

3.title: Input Assistance
3.description: Help users avoid and correct mistakes.

4.title: Robust
4.description: Content must be robust enough that it can be interpreted by a wide variety of user agents, including assistive technologies.

1.title: Compatible
1.description: Maximize compatibility with current and future user agents, including assistive technologies.
